body: I think cycle detection won't win us anything, because it could fail only in runtime, but it fails with StackOverflowError already.
At least the error message would be clearer if it identified the cycle.
But supporting IdentityHashMap of already visited references has a non-trivial cost.
@gianm thanks!
@leventov do you have any benchmarks on the impact of using the iterator instead of the older for loop methodology in some of these potentially tight loops?
I haven't been able to review the code but please make sure it is possible to roll back and forth across versions during an upgrade without loosing the cache.

@drcrallen the only potentially performance-sensitive place that is changed is `StringDimensionIndexer`, but there iteration over array (not `Iterable`) is replaced with for-each. For-each over an array translated into identical bytecode, as manual indexed loop.

@akashdw I can post "full metrics" PR because essentially I already have it implemented internally (minus some specifics which I can remove). After that PR is merged, you could add blacklist configs to "FullMetrics" specifically, with defined semantics, not QueryMetrics "in general". E. g. it will look like

```
druid.query.topN.queryMetricsFactory=full
druid.query.topN.queryMetrics.full.excludeDimensions=[...]
druid.query.topN.queryMetrics.full.excludeMetrics=[...]
```

I'm closing and reopening this pr to trigger travis.

@DaimonPl some thoughts:

- The "98% right" thing is meant to refer to average error of HyperLogLog, but certainly the error in any particular case can be greater than that.
- Druid's implementation deviates from the standard algorithm (see http://druid.io/blog/2014/02/18/hyperloglog-optimizations-for-real-world-systems.html) in a way that decreases storage space but can increase the error slightly in some cases.
- Yes changing the number of buckets is a good way to improve the accuracy. In addition you could undo the storage space optimization.
- But watch out since both of the above changes would affect the storage format, meaning you may be incompatible with already-written hyperUnique columns.
@SpotXPeterCunningham thanks, will merge this PR tomorrow unless somebody else wants to review.

Definitely looks like a bug of some sort.

Does the inner query on query 2 run successfully if you run it by itself? This one:

```sql
select 
        max(__time) as __time,
        primary_id,
        details_result
    from data_soure
    where 1=1
        and event_name = 'event_name_3'
        and floor(__time to day) > current_timestamp - interval '30' day
    group by primary_id,details_result
```

And what version of Druid are running (or if you built it yourself, what commit)?

Finally: Could you contribute a test case for `io.druid.sql.calcite.CalciteQueryTest` that reproduces this error? That'd help a ton in tracking it down.

> that said, once a historical is blacklisted, will user need to take some action to "un-blacklist" it or will it be something of a temporary blacklisting ?

I think ideally, there should be some backoff. So let's say a node is blacklisted when it has some problems, and then after some time has passed, we'll let it load a few segments (applying a throttle) as a test. If it can do those, then take off the throttle and return it to full service. If it can't do those, then return it to a full blacklist for another while.

I reviewed the druid-sql part and it looks good to me. I am also +1 on the general design. But I haven't done code level review of anything outside druid-sql.

Has anyone else reviewed the rest? Or does it still need code level review?
@jihoonson I think all checks passed this time.
Seems like what's really wanted is being able to write your own cache lookup sql query, and then being able to map any of the result set columns.
any one ? thanks

@leventov sure, here it is. I added a new benchmark query because there wasn't a query having a single grouping key except ```simple``` series queries which cause a lot of GCs due to too large cardinality of the grouping column. Not dramatically fast, but looks worthwhile.

```
master

# Run complete. Total time: 00:01:03

Benchmark                                   (defaultStrategy)  (initialBuckets)  (numProcessingThreads)  (numSegments)  (queryGranularity)  (rowsPerSegment)  (schemaAndQuery)  Mode  Cnt      Score     Error  Units
GroupByBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                 v2                -1                       1              1                 all           1000000  basic.singleZipf  avgt   30  72984.855 ± 258.569  us/op

patch

Benchmark                                   (defaultStrategy)  (initialBuckets)  (numProcessingThreads)  (numSegments)  (queryGranularity)  (rowsPerSegment)  (schemaAndQuery)  Mode  Cnt      Score     Error  Units
GroupByBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                 v2                -1                       1              1                 all           1000000  basic.singleZipf  avgt   30  70874.918 ± 396.666  us/op
```

yeah, i would prefer temporary blacklisting aka backoff instead of permanently marking a node blacklisted.

@kaijianding 

> As far as I know, only groupby v1 and topN query uses the reserved processing directly memory. The number of processing thread is limited due to the memory ls limited (like 16g or 32g per jvm).

groupBy v2 does use the processing buffers too, although if they are limited in size, performance shouldn't be hurt too much. So you can cut them down to 100MB or so and see how that works for you.

timeseries doesn't use them at all.

@sascha-coenen Thanks for the comments!

>"When a set of segments are merged during indexing". In which situations would segments be merged? Only in a Merge Task or any hadoop index task or only in re-indexing tasks? Is it correct to assume that "indexing" is something that only happens during the ingestion of data, so it is not happening on broker/historical, right? To my understanding, "indexing" is the creation of an index which would happen only during the ingestion of data, but then again, in the query phase, segments get scanned and segments contain indexes and they get merged and there are merge buffers, so I was wondering whether "segment merging during indexing" only refers to the index creation in the ingestion phase or also something that happens during query processing? I think its the first but I'm insecure...

"indexing" used in this context is referring to "ingestion",  so merge tasks, hadoop index tasks, re-indexing tasks, kafka supervisor tasks, etc. can all involve segment merging. (From a code perspective, things that use IndexMerger).

I updated the doc changes in this PR to mention "ingestion" instead of "indexing" to be more clear.

> "fuzzy parameter meant to account for the decompression and dictionary merging buffers"
Prior to this phrase, the documentation mentions "merge buffers" but I got the feeling that "dictionary merge buffers" are yet something else. If so, it would be great to get a brief explanation of what they are and where they come into play (historicals? / brokers? etc)

The dictionary merge buffers are described in the second point under "Other sources of direct memory usage include:", I updated that with a point about how these buffers are independent of the other "merge buffers".

> "Indexing workers and historical"
I've been working with Druid for 18 months now but I'm still insecure about the use of the term "Indexing" as the documentation as a whole explains terms like overlord/middlemanager/peons/realtime nodes but then uses terms like "indexing service" or "indexing workers" and I don't know what exactly how these notions connect. What exactly is meant by "Indexing workers" in this case? Does it mean Peons/Middlemanagers? Other documentation also sometimes talks of "indexing service" in which case I'm not sure if "indexing service" is the short form of "Kafka Indexing service" or if "indexing-service" == overlord+middlemanagers+peons or if Indexing service == realtime nodes... I do feel that I understand all concepts and moving parts of Druid, it's just the terminology itself that throws me. A reoccuring pattern is that I read about similar terms and don't know if they are synonymous or not.

"Indexing workers" in this PR was referring to worker tasks that perform ingestion (peons), spawned by the overlord or middlemanager.

>Below the newly added documentation, there is a section that says
"Larger values allow for more aggregations in a single pass over the data while smaller values can require more passes depending on the query that is being executed"
How can I tell whether Druid is needing several passes over the data? To my understanding, in order to achieve top performance, Druid should be doing only a single pass over the data. Therefore, I would like to make the processsing buffers sufficiently large such that for all query scenarios that can occur on my particular cluster, all query processing would be done in a single-pass fashion. So how can I tell whether that is actually happening? Lets say I have a testsuite covering all query scenarios over my particular dataset. How can I measure how many passes Druid ends up taking given my current memory settings? There is a segment scan time metric and if it is too high, that might indicate several passes, but thats just a fuzzy measure. Is there a way to read off how many passes were taken? Is this being logged or emitted as a metric?

I'm not aware of any existing metrics or logs that track number of query passes

Got this exception in 0.10.1. Actually it was due to incorrect Jackson annotation usage:
```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Argument #0 of constructor
```
While the previously mentioned stacktrace says it cannot print out the root cause description:
```
com.sun.jersey.api.MessageException: A message body writer for Java class com.google.common.collect.SingletonImmutableBiMap, and Java type class com.google.common.collect.SingletonImmutableBiMap
```
To find the root cause I had to attach the debugger at `jersey-server-1.19.3-sources.jar!/com/sun/jersey/spi/container/ContainerResponse.java:271`
@leventov Current contract of this method does allow for mutation of the input objects and it is callers responsibility to not to use lhs or rhs after calling this method.

It's not currently possible. See #4373 for a proposal around making it possible.

Closing this since it's a duplicate of #4373.

@akashdw it's not under caller control to not use those objects during querying. Nevertheless I'm going to fix this, the part is already in #4676, where AggreagateCombiner.combine() does _not_ allow to modify input objects.

@niketh i knew this as well....but this wasn't related to my earlier pr which the issue described. UniformGranularitySpec bucketInterval has had this assumption that it will be invoked with wrappedSpec for a while now. Do you know why? Anyway I've added the protection for now.

@leventov mutation of lhs is done in thetaSketch to improve performance... if querying them causes any exceptions/bug then that needs to be fixed appropriately in the thetaSketch extension code.
extension writer should be free to mutate the objects, it is creating, if necessary (mostly done for performance )

@himanshug all object aggregators that I listed amend data into `lhs`. It probably never causes any exceptions, but makes the query results wrong. Extension author could make nothing with it, if he decides to mutate the `lhs`. The solution in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/projects/2 will be just to retire `AggregatorFactory.combine()`. `AggregateCombiner` prohibits mutation, but it doesn't limit performance, because of different design.
@praveev The check for `wrappedSpec` should have been added earlier, looks like it's a miss. Also, can you open/close your PR. There is a flaky test because of which the build is failing.
@leventov its fine as long as we don't end up unnecessarily cloning sketches.
@himanshug you can review #4676
changed to set the property in `TestBroker`
